isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION CARRIERS: ROCKWELL - DISASSEMBLE - DISASSEMBLE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE

svcproc.title: DISASSEMBLE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE

step1.para: Put the drive pinion and bearing cage in a press. The pinion shaft must be toward the top of the assembly ( Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 29. Put Drive Pinion and Bearing Cage in Press

step1.para: Support the bearing cage under the flange area with metal or wood blocks ( Figure 30).

figure.caption: Figure 30. Press Pinion Shaft Through Bearing Cage

step1.para: Press the pinion shaft through the bearing cage ( Figure 30).

note.para: The inner bearing cone and bearing spacer or spacers will remain on the pinion shaft.

warning.para: Wear safe eye protection. Do not hit steel parts with a steel hammer. Parts can break and cause injury.

step1.para: If a press is not available, use a leather, plastic or rubber mallet to drive the pinion shaft through the bearing cage.

If the pinion oil seal is mounted directly in the outer bore of the bearing cage, remove the seal at this time. Be careful that you do not damage the mounting surfaces of the bearing cage ( Figure 31).
If the seal is a one-piece design (without mounting flange), discard the seal.

If the oil seal is a triple-lip design (with flange), inspect the seal for damage. If the surfaces of the seal and the yoke or flange are smooth and not worn or damaged, you can use the seal again when you assemble the carrier.

caution.para: Be careful when using a screwdriver or pry bar to remove the seal. Do not damage the wall of bore. Damage to the bore can cause oil leaks.

step1.para: If the pinion bearings need to be replaced, remove the inner and outer bearing cups from the inside of cage. Use a press and sleeve, bearing puller or a small drift and hammer. The type of tool used depends on the design of the bearing cage ( Figure 32).

figure.caption: Figure 32. Remove Inner and Outer Bearing Cups From Inside of Cage

step1.para: When a press is used, support the bearing cage under the flange area with metal or wood blocks.

If the pinion bearings need to be replaced, remove the inner bearing cone from the pinion shaft with a press or bearing puller. The puller MUST fit under the inner race of the cone to remove the cone correctly without damage ( Figure 33).

figure.caption: Figure 33. Remove Inner Bearing Cone From Pinion Shaft

step1.para: If the spigot bearing needs to be replaced, put the drive pinion in a vise. Install a soft metal cover over each vise jaw to protect the drive pinion.
Remove the snap ring * from the end of drive pinion with snap ring pliers that expand ( Figure 34).

figure.caption: Figure 34. Remove Snap Ring From End of Drive Pinion

note.para: Some spigot bearings are fastened to the pinion shaft with a special peening tool ( Figure 35).

figure.caption: Figure 35. Fasten Spigot Bearings With Special Peening Tool

step1.para: Remove the spigot bearing from the pinion shaft with a bearing puller ( Figure 36).

figure.caption: Figure 36. Remove Spigot Bearing From Pinion Shaft

note.para: Some spigot bearings are a two-piece assembly. Remove the inner race from the pinion shaft with a bearing puller. Remove the outer race/roller assembly from carrier with a drift or a press ( Figure 37).

figure.caption: Figure 37. Remove Inner and Outer Race
